canonical_explanation.text: The human body can move because of the skeletal system (bones) and muscular system (muscles) working together. The human skeleton has 206 bones that provide shape, support, and protection. Bones are connected at joints, which allow different types of movement. A ball and socket joint (at the shoulder and hip) allows movement in all directions. A hinge joint (at the knee and elbow) allows movement in only one direction, like a door hinge. A pivot joint (at the neck) allows rotational movement. Fixed joints (in the skull) do not allow any movement. Cartilage is a softer, more flexible tissue found at the tip of the nose, in the ear, and between vertebrae. Muscles are attached to bones and cause movement by contracting (becoming shorter) and relaxing (becoming longer). They work in pairs. Different animals move in different ways: earthworms use muscles to expand and contract their body; snails use a muscular foot; fish use fins and tail; birds use wings; and snakes use their long spine and muscles to slither.
rules: The skeleton provides shape, support, protection, and helps in movement.
Ball and socket joint allows movement in all directions (shoulder, hip).
Hinge joint allows movement in one direction only (knee, elbow).
Fixed joints do not allow any movement (skull).
Cartilage is softer and more flexible than bone (nose tip, ear, between vertebrae).
Muscles work in pairs — when one contracts, the other relaxes.
The rib cage protects the heart and lungs.
The backbone (vertebral column) consists of 33 small bones called vertebrae.
Different animals have different body structures suited to their modes of movement.

questions.question_text: How many bones are there in an adult human body?
questions.explanation_correct: An adult human body has 206 bones. These bones together form the skeletal system, which provides shape, support, protection, and helps in movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct number of bones in an adult human body is 206, not 106, 306, or 406. This is a standard fact about the human skeletal system.

questions.question_text: The joint at the shoulder is an example of a:
questions.explanation_correct: The shoulder joint is a ball and socket joint. In this joint, the rounded end (ball) of one bone fits into the hollow space (socket) of another bone, allowing movement in all directions.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Hinge joints are at the knee and elbow. Pivot joints are at the neck. Fixed joints are in the skull. The shoulder is a ball and socket joint that allows movement in all directions.

questions.question_text: Which type of joint allows movement in only one direction, like a door?
questions.explanation_correct: A hinge joint allows movement in only one direction (back and forth), just like a door hinge. Examples include the knee joint and elbow joint.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ball and socket joints allow movement in all directions. Pivot joints allow rotation. Gliding joints allow small sliding movements. Hinge joints are the ones that work like a door, allowing movement in one direction.

questions.question_text: The joint in the neck that allows us to turn our head from side to side is a:
questions.explanation_correct: The neck has a pivot joint that allows the head to rotate from side to side and nod up and down. In a pivot joint, one bone rotates around another fixed bone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fixed joints allow no movement. Hinge joints allow back-and-forth movement. Ball and socket joints allow movement in all directions. The pivot joint in the neck specifically allows the rotational movement of the head.

questions.question_text: The joints in the skull are:
questions.explanation_correct: The joints in the skull are fixed joints (also called immovable joints). The bones of the skull are fused together and do not allow any movement. This provides strong protection for the brain.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The skull bones need to be firmly joined to protect the brain, so they have fixed joints that do not allow any movement. Hinge, ball and socket, and pivot joints all allow movement.

questions.question_text: The hip joint is a ball and socket joint.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The hip joint, like the shoulder joint, is a ball and socket joint. It allows the leg to move in all directions — forward, backward, and sideways.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. The hip joint is indeed a ball and socket joint where the round head of the thigh bone (femur) fits into a socket in the hip bone (pelvis).

questions.question_text: When you bend your arm to lift a bag, the joint involved is the:

options.text: Ball and socket joint at the hip

questions.explanation_correct: When you bend your arm at the elbow to lift something, you are using the hinge joint at the elbow. The hinge joint allows the forearm to bend in one direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The neck has a pivot joint (for head rotation). The skull has fixed joints (no movement). The hip has a ball and socket joint (for leg movement). Bending the arm uses the hinge joint at the elbow.

questions.question_text: Rohan can rotate his arm in a full circle at the shoulder but can only bend his leg back and forth at the knee. This is because:

options.text: The knee has a ball and socket joint and the shoulder has a hinge joint
The shoulder has a ball and socket joint and the knee has a hinge joint
Both have ball and socket joints

questions.explanation_correct: The shoulder has a ball and socket joint which allows movement in all directions (full circle rotation). The knee has a hinge joint which allows movement in only one direction (back and forth, like bending the leg).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The different ranges of movement are due to different joint types. Ball and socket joints (shoulder) allow rotation in all directions. Hinge joints (knee) allow only back-and-forth movement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following organs is protected by the rib cage?
questions.explanation_correct: The rib cage protects the heart and lungs. It is made up of 12 pairs of ribs that form a cage-like structure around these vital organs in the chest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is protected by the skull, not the rib cage. While kidneys are partially protected by ribs, the primary organs the rib cage protects are the heart and lungs.

questions.question_text: The skull protects which important organ?
questions.explanation_correct: The skull protects the brain. It is a hard, bony structure that forms a protective case around the brain, shielding it from injuries.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Heart and lungs are protected by the rib cage. Liver is protected by the lower ribs. The skull specifically protects the brain.

questions.question_text: Cartilage is found in which of the following parts of the body?
questions.explanation_correct: Cartilage is found in the ear (pinna), the tip of the nose, and between the vertebrae of the backbone. You can feel how the ear is flexible and bendy — that is because it is made of cartilage, not bone.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The upper arm has the humerus bone. The skull is made of hard bones. The thigh has the femur bone. The ear (pinna) is made of cartilage, which is softer and more flexible than bone.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is a function of the skeleton?

options.text: Giving shape and support to the body

questions.explanation_correct: The skeleton gives shape and support to the body. Without the skeleton, our body would be like a bag without any form. The skeleton also protects internal organs and helps in movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Digesting food is done by the digestive system. Pumping blood is done by the heart. Filtering waste is done by kidneys. Giving shape, support, and protection is the function of the skeleton.

questions.question_text: The backbone (vertebral column) is made up of how many small bones called vertebrae?
questions.explanation_correct: The backbone or vertebral column is made up of 33 small bones called vertebrae. They are arranged one on top of another with cartilage (discs) between them, allowing the backbone to bend.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct number is 33 vertebrae. These are stacked in a column and held together by muscles and ligaments, with cartilage discs between them for flexibility.

questions.question_text: Why can we bend our backbone but not our skull?

options.text: Backbone has joints with cartilage between vertebrae, skull has fixed joints
Backbone has no bones, only muscles

questions.explanation_correct: The backbone has cartilage (discs) between each vertebra, allowing some movement and flexibility. The skull has fixed joints where bones are fused together, not allowing any movement. This is why we can bend our backbone but not our skull.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The backbone does have bones (33 vertebrae), but with flexible cartilage between them. The skull is made of bones (not cartilage) with fixed joints. The difference in joint type explains the difference in flexibility.

questions.question_text: Cartilage is different from bone because cartilage is:

options.text: Harder and less flexible than bone
Softer and more flexible than bone
Not found in the human body

questions.explanation_correct: Cartilage is softer and more flexible than bone. You can feel this by pressing your ear or nose tip — they can bend, unlike hard bones. Cartilage acts as a cushion between bones at joints.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cartilage is not harder than bone (it is softer). It is not the same as bone. It is definitely found in the human body (ears, nose, joints). Cartilage is softer and more flexible than bone.

questions.question_text: Muscles cause movement by:
questions.explanation_correct: Muscles cause movement by contracting (becoming shorter and thicker) and relaxing (becoming longer and thinner). When a muscle contracts, it pulls the bone it is attached to, causing movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscles do not grow longer, break apart, or stay the same during movement. They work by alternately contracting and relaxing, pulling on bones to create movement.

questions.question_text: Muscles work in:
questions.explanation_correct: Muscles work in pairs. When one muscle in the pair contracts, the other relaxes. For example, when you bend your arm, the biceps contracts and the triceps relaxes. When you straighten your arm, the triceps contracts and the biceps relaxes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscles do not work alone or in groups of three or five. They work in pairs — when one muscle contracts to cause a movement, its partner muscle relaxes, and vice versa.

questions.question_text: When you bend your arm at the elbow, the biceps muscle:
questions.explanation_correct: When you bend your arm at the elbow, the biceps muscle contracts (becomes shorter and thicker), pulling the forearm upward. Meanwhile, the triceps muscle on the back of the arm relaxes.
questions.explanation_incorrect: When bending the arm, the biceps contracts (shortens) to pull the forearm up. It does not relax, stay the same, or detach. Muscles must contract (shorten) to create a pulling force.

questions.question_text: How does an earthworm move?

options.text: By alternately extending and contracting its body using muscles

questions.explanation_correct: An earthworm moves by alternately extending and contracting its body segments using muscles. Tiny bristles (setae) on its body grip the ground and prevent it from slipping backward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Earthworms do not have wings, fins, or legs. They move using their muscles to extend and contract their body segments, with tiny bristles (setae) helping them grip the surface.

questions.question_text: A snail moves with the help of its:
questions.explanation_correct: A snail moves with the help of its muscular foot. The foot produces a slimy substance (mucus) that helps the snail slide smoothly over surfaces.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Snails do not have wings, fins, or a tail. They have a single, large muscular foot on their underside that they use to glide slowly over surfaces.

questions.question_text: Which of the following helps a fish move through water?
questions.explanation_correct: Fish use their fins and tail to swim through water. The tail fin pushes the fish forward, while other fins help with steering, balancing, and stopping. Their streamlined body shape also reduces water resistance.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fish do not have legs, arms, or wings. They do not have a muscular foot like a snail. Fish use fins for steering and balance, and the tail fin for forward propulsion.

questions.question_text: A snake does not have legs. How does it move?

options.text: By slithering using its long backbone and muscles
By using its tail as a propeller

questions.explanation_correct: A snake moves by slithering. It has a very long backbone with many vertebrae and strong muscles. The muscles push against the ground in a wavy S-shaped motion, propelling the snake forward.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Snakes do not hop, roll, or use their tail as a propeller. They move by creating S-shaped curves using their long backbone (many vertebrae) and muscles, pushing against the ground to slither forward.

questions.question_text: A cockroach can walk, climb, and fly. For flying, it uses its:
questions.explanation_correct: A cockroach has two pairs of wings that it uses for flying. The outer pair is thick and protects the inner wings. The inner pair is thin and membranous, used for actual flight.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The three pairs of legs are used for walking and climbing. Cockroaches do not have a muscular foot or tail for flying. They use their two pairs of wings for flight.

questions.question_text: Priya shook her head to say 'no'. Which type of joint did she use?
questions.explanation_correct: Shaking the head from side to side (to say 'no') involves the pivot joint in the neck. This joint allows the head to rotate left and right.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ball and socket joints are at the shoulder and hip. Hinge joints are at the knee and elbow. Fixed joints do not allow movement. The pivoting (rotational) motion of the head uses the pivot joint in the neck.

questions.question_text: If the rib cage were not present, which organs would be most at risk?
questions.explanation_correct: Without the rib cage, the heart and lungs would be unprotected and vulnerable to injury. The rib cage forms a bony cage around these vital organs in the chest.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is protected by the skull. The spinal cord is protected by the vertebral column. Eyes and ears are protected by skull bones. The heart and lungs are specifically protected by the rib cage.

questions.question_text: Why can muscles only pull bones and not push them?

options.text: Muscles are too weak to push
Muscles can only contract (shorten), creating a pulling action
Bones are too heavy to push
Muscles are not attached to bones

questions.explanation_correct: Muscles can only contract (become shorter), which creates a pulling force on the bones they are attached to. They cannot push because they cannot expand on their own — they can only shorten. This is why muscles work in pairs: one pulls in one direction, the other pulls in the opposite direction.
questions.explanation_incorrect: It is not about muscle weakness or bone weight. Muscles are attached to bones but can only generate force by contracting (shortening). This creates only a pulling action, which is why opposing pairs of muscles are needed.

questions.question_text:
Match the animal with its method of movement:
(i) Fish — (P) Wings
(ii) Bird — (Q) Muscular foot
(iii) Snail — (R) Fins and tail
(iv) Earthworm — (S) Body muscles (extend and contract)
questions.explanation_correct: Fish use fins and tail (R), birds use wings (P), snails use a muscular foot (Q), and earthworms use body muscles that extend and contract (S).
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct matches are: Fish — fins and tail, Bird — wings, Snail — muscular foot, Earthworm — body muscles. Only option A has all four correct.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists joints from MOST movement to LEAST movement?

options.text: Fixed joint → Hinge joint → Ball and socket joint
Ball and socket joint → Hinge joint → Fixed joint
Hinge joint → Fixed joint → Ball and socket joint
Pivot joint → Ball and socket joint → Hinge joint

questions.explanation_correct: From most movement to least: Ball and socket joint (movement in all directions) → Hinge joint (movement in one direction) → Fixed joint (no movement at all).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Ball and socket joints allow the most movement (all directions). Hinge joints allow moderate movement (one direction). Fixed joints allow no movement. The correct order from most to least is B.

questions.question_text:
Assertion: The bones of the skull are joined by fixed joints.
Reason: The brain needs strong protection, so the skull bones must not move.

options.text: Both assertion and reason are correct, and reason explains the assertion
Both assertion and reason are correct, but reason does not explain the assertion
Assertion is correct but reason is incorrect
Assertion is incorrect but reason is correct

questions.explanation_correct: The assertion is correct — skull bones have fixed joints. The reason is also correct and explains why — the brain needs rigid, unmoving protection, which is why the skull bones are fused together at fixed joints.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Both statements are correct. The skull bones are indeed joined by fixed joints, and this is because the brain needs strong, immovable protection. The reason explains why fixed joints are present in the skull.

questions.question_text: When you straighten your bent arm, which of the following happens?
questions.explanation_correct: When straightening a bent arm, the triceps (muscle at the back of the upper arm) contracts and the biceps (muscle at the front) relaxes. This is the opposite of what happens when bending the arm.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscles work in pairs with opposite actions. When bending: biceps contracts, triceps relaxes. When straightening: triceps contracts, biceps relaxes. Both cannot contract or relax at the same time for this movement.

questions.question_text: The place where two bones meet is called a _______.
questions.explanation_correct: A joint is the place where two or more bones meet. Joints allow different types and amounts of movement depending on their type.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Muscles are tissues that contract and relax. Cartilage is a flexible tissue. Tendons connect muscles to bones. The place where two bones meet is called a joint.

questions.question_text: Birds fly using their:
questions.explanation_correct: Birds fly using their wings. Wings are modified forelimbs with flight feathers that allow birds to generate lift and thrust for flying.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While the tail helps in steering, birds primarily use their wings for flight. Legs are for walking and perching. The beak is for eating. Wings are the main structures used for flying.

questions.question_text: The body of a fish is streamlined. This shape helps the fish to:

options.text: Move through water with less resistance

questions.explanation_correct: The streamlined (tapering at both ends) body shape of a fish helps it move through water with less resistance (friction). This shape allows water to flow smoothly over the body, making swimming easier and faster.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fish breathe through gills. Streamlining does not help find food or stay warm. The streamlined shape specifically reduces water resistance, allowing the fish to swim efficiently.

questions.question_text: A cricket player throws a ball using his arm. The joints involved in this action include:

options.text: Only the hinge joint at the elbow
Only the ball and socket joint at the shoulder
Both the ball and socket joint at the shoulder and the hinge joint at the elbow
Only the fixed joint in the wrist

questions.explanation_correct: Throwing a ball involves the ball and socket joint at the shoulder (to swing the arm in different directions) and the hinge joint at the elbow (to extend and release the ball). Multiple joints work together for complex movements.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Throwing a ball requires movement at multiple joints. The shoulder joint allows the arm to swing, and the elbow joint allows the arm to extend. Both work together for the throwing action.

questions.question_text: The vertebral column (backbone) protects the spinal cord.
questions.explanation_correct: This is true. The vertebral column (backbone) has a hollow canal through which the spinal cord passes. The vertebrae protect the delicate spinal cord from damage.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The statement is correct. The backbone forms a bony tunnel that houses and protects the spinal cord, which carries nerve signals between the brain and the rest of the body.

questions.question_text: What would happen if muscles could NOT relax?

options.text: The body would not be able to move at all
Only the arms would stop moving

questions.explanation_correct: If muscles could not relax, the body would not be able to move. Movement requires muscles to work in pairs — one contracts while the other relaxes. If muscles could only contract and never relax, they would stay permanently shortened and no movement would be possible.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Movement depends on the coordinated contraction and relaxation of muscle pairs. If muscles could not relax, all muscles would be permanently contracted and stiff, preventing any body movement.

questions.question_text: An earthworm has tiny bristles (setae) on its body. These bristles help the earthworm to:

options.text: Grip the ground and prevent slipping backward

questions.explanation_correct: The tiny bristles (setae) on an earthworm's body grip the ground surface and prevent the worm from slipping backward as it pushes itself forward. Without these bristles, the earthworm would not be able to move effectively.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Earthworms breathe through their moist skin. They do not have eyes. Water absorption is not the primary function of setae. The bristles specifically help grip the ground for effective movement.

questions.question_text: Which of the following activities uses a hinge joint?

options.text: Nodding your head up and down
Rotating your arm in a circle
Moving your jaw to chew food

questions.explanation_correct: Kicking a football involves extending the leg at the knee, which is a hinge joint. The knee allows the lower leg to swing forward in one direction, just like a door hinge.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Nodding uses the pivot joint in the neck. Rotating the arm uses the ball and socket joint at the shoulder. The jaw joint is a modified hinge joint but kicking is the clearest example of a hinge joint (knee) in action.

questions.question_text: A person met with an accident and fractured a rib. The doctor was most concerned about injury to the:
questions.explanation_correct: Since the rib cage protects the heart and lungs, a fractured rib could potentially injure the lungs. A broken rib could puncture or damage the lung tissue, which is why the doctor would be most concerned about the lungs.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The brain is protected by the skull (not ribs). While the stomach and kidneys are nearby, the lungs are directly behind the ribs and most at risk from a rib fracture.

questions.question_text: What connects muscles to bones?
questions.explanation_correct: Tendons are strong, flexible tissues that connect muscles to bones. When a muscle contracts, the tendon pulls on the bone, causing movement at the joint.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cartilage is found at joint surfaces and in the ear/nose. Ligaments connect bone to bone. Joints are where bones meet. Tendons specifically connect muscles to bones.

questions.question_text: A cockroach has how many pairs of legs?
questions.explanation_correct: A cockroach has three pairs of legs (six legs in total). It is an insect, and all insects have three pairs of jointed legs. The cockroach also has two pairs of wings.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Cockroaches, like all insects, have exactly three pairs (six) of legs. They are not arachnids (four pairs) or crustaceans. Three pairs of legs is a defining feature of insects.

questions.question_text: Which of the following animals has a skeleton OUTSIDE its body (exoskeleton)?
questions.explanation_correct: A cockroach has an exoskeleton — a hard outer covering that protects its body and provides support. Fish, snakes, and frogs all have internal skeletons (endoskeletons).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Fish, snakes, and frogs all have internal skeletons (bones inside the body). The cockroach has an exoskeleton — a hard external shell that acts as both armour and structural support.

questions.question_text:
A student made the following observations:
(i) She can rotate her head — Joint X
(ii) She can swing her arm in a circle — Joint Y
(iii) She can bend and straighten her knee — Joint Z
Identify joints X, Y, and Z:
questions.explanation_correct: Rotating the head uses a pivot joint (X). Swinging the arm in a circle uses the ball and socket joint at the shoulder (Y). Bending and straightening the knee uses a hinge joint (Z).
questions.explanation_incorrect: Head rotation = pivot joint, arm circular movement = ball and socket joint, knee bending = hinge joint. Only option A correctly identifies all three joints.

questions.question_text: Which of the following correctly lists the protective structures and the organs they protect?

options.text: Skull — Brain, Rib cage — Heart and Lungs, Backbone — Spinal cord
Rib cage — Brain, Skull — Spinal cord

questions.explanation_correct: Skull protects the brain, rib cage protects the heart and lungs, and the backbone (vertebral column) protects the spinal cord. These are the three main protective functions of the skeleton.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The correct protective relationships are: skull protects brain, rib cage protects heart and lungs, backbone protects spinal cord. Only option B lists all three correctly.

questions.question_text: In which of the following situations are muscles NOT involved?
questions.explanation_correct: Growth of hair does not involve muscle contraction and relaxation. Hair grows from follicles in the skin and does not require muscular movement. Running, chewing, and lifting all require muscles to contract and relax.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Running uses leg and body muscles. Chewing uses jaw muscles. Lifting uses arm and hand muscles. Hair growth is a biological process in hair follicles that does not require muscle movement.

questions.question_text:
Which of the following features helps a bird fly?
(i) Hollow bones
(ii) Wings with feathers
(iii) Streamlined body
(iv) Heavy skeleton
questions.explanation_correct: Hollow bones (make the bird lighter), wings with feathers (generate lift and thrust), and a streamlined body (reduce air resistance) all help a bird fly. A heavy skeleton would hinder flight, not help it.
questions.explanation_incorrect: A heavy skeleton would make it harder for a bird to fly. The features that help birds fly are hollow bones (lighter weight), wings with feathers (for flight), and streamlined body (less air resistance).

questions.question_text: Which of the following body movements involves a pivot joint?

options.text: Swinging the arm at the shoulder
Turning the head to look sideways

questions.explanation_correct: Turning the head to look sideways involves the pivot joint in the neck. The first vertebra (atlas) rotates on the second vertebra (axis), allowing the head to turn.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bending the knee and fingers involve hinge joints. Swinging the arm at the shoulder involves a ball and socket joint. Turning the head sideways specifically uses the pivot joint in the neck.

questions.question_text: Bones can move on their own without muscles.
questions.explanation_correct: This is false. Bones cannot move on their own. They need muscles to pull them. When muscles contract, they pull on the bones through tendons, causing movement at the joints.
questions.explanation_incorrect: Bones are rigid structures that cannot move by themselves. Movement occurs only when muscles contract and pull on the bones. Without muscles, the skeleton would be a static framework.

questions.question_text: The snail produces a slimy substance (mucus) while moving. This mucus helps the snail to:
questions.explanation_correct: The mucus (slime) produced by a snail reduces friction between its muscular foot and the ground surface, allowing the snail to slide smoothly, even over rough surfaces. It also protects the snail's foot from sharp objects.
questions.explanation_incorrect: The mucus is primarily for locomotion, not for eating, breathing, or navigation. It creates a smooth, lubricated surface that allows the snail's muscular foot to glide over surfaces.

questions.question_text: Which of the following is the BEST reason why the skeletal system is important for movement?

options.text: Bones provide a rigid framework for muscles to pull against

questions.explanation_correct: The skeletal system is important for movement because bones provide a rigid framework that muscles can pull against. Without this rigid structure, muscle contraction would not produce effective body movement.
questions.explanation_incorrect: While bones do produce blood cells and store calcium, these are not related to movement. Bones do not produce heat. For movement, the key role of bones is providing a rigid framework for muscles to pull on.
